docs.lead_paragraph: Wherever she went, flaunting her bad wigs and diamonds and hostile charm, something seemed to disappear: a neighbor's wristwatch in Las Vegas, a car from a dealer's lot in Honolulu, a mink coat from a piano bar in Washington. Then, it was people who vanished. There were the Mexican women taken for slaves in her homes in California, Hawaii and Nevada. There was the banker in the Bahamas who met her for dinner and was never seen again. There was the Los Angeles businessman who knew enough to be terrified of her. He was found shot to death.

headline.main: A FAMILY PORTRAIT: A special report.; A Twisted Tale of Deceit, Fraud and Violence

docs.abstract: Special report, A Family Portrait, traces Sante Kimes' long career in fraud, swindling, arson and theft as New York police investigate disappearance of Edith Silverman, 82-year-old wealthy eccentric and apparent latest victim of Kimes and her 23-year-old son, Kenneth; Kimes was born Sandra Walker in Oklahoma in 1935, married wealthy motel and property owner and lived with him and their son in Honolulu and Las Vegas, serving prison sentence along the way for enslaving Mexican servants; Kenneth Kimes hated and feared domineering mother, and led more normal life as high school and college student while she was in jail, but joined her fraud schemes after father died in 1994; they are suspected in 1996 disappearance of Syed Bilal Ahmed in Bahamas and in murder of David J Kazdin in Los Angeles last March; photos; two were arrested in New York on bad-check complaint by Utah car dealer, and are being held as police seek clues to Silverman's fate (L)

byline.original: By ROBERT D. McFADDEN with FRANK BRUNI

docs.section_name: Front Page; New York and Region

docs.lead_paragraph: A coalition of 25 health maintenance organizations said today that it was willing to accept substantial Federal regulation -- much more than the Republican leaders of Congress want. In a move that they said should restore public confidence in their industry as it is buffeted by sharp partisan attacks, the H.M.O.'s endorsed a series of guarantees, including coverage of emergency room care, grievance and appeal procedures for patients and assured access to medical specialists.

headline.main: H.M.O. Group Backs Controls G.O.P. Rejects

docs.abstract: Coalition of 25 health maintenance organizations says it is willing to accept substantial Federal regulation, even more than lawmakers want, in order to restore public confidence in their industry; HMO Group, mostly nonprofits, endorses guarantees, including coverage of emergency-room care, grievance and appeal procedures and assured access to specialists; balks at Democratic demands to expand patients' ability to sue when medical benefits are improperly denied; backs compromise bill of Sens John Chafee and Bob Graham (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Formally starting a re-election campaign that has been under way for a year, Gov. John G. Rowland of Connecticut declared today that his top priority in a second term would be helping to rebuild the decaying cores of the state's largest cities. That choice as a campaign centerpiece is part of a continuing effort by Mr. Rowland, a Republican, to chart a course that he calls ''fiscally conservative and socially inclusive.'' It also reflects the evolution of the ever-more-moderate Mr. Rowland, 41, who went to Congress in 1985 as a brash right-winger and won the gubernatorial race in 1994, a year of big Republican gains.

headline.main: Rowland Opens Re-election Effort With a Pledge to Cities

docs.abstract: Connecticut Gov John G Rowland, formally starting re-election campaign that has been under way for a year, declares that his top priority in second term will be helping to rebuild decaying cores of state's largest cities; Rowland has wide lead in polls over Democratic challenger, Rep Barbara B Kennelly, and has set state record for governor's race by raising $4.3 million; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: It began 39 days ago as a simple strike at a single General Motors factory over how modern-day workers should build fenders and hoods. But like two neighborhood toughs daring each other with escalating taunts, G.M. and the United Automobile Workers union have fallen into a dispute so big, complicated and destructive that a solution now seems more elusive than ever. The strike has forced G.M. to lay off 165,000 workers across North America and close 26 of 29 assembly plants. Any hope of resolving it soon was dealt a big setback this weekend when both sides threw up their hands in frustration.
docs.abstract: Analysis of face-off at General Motors, which began 39 days ago as simple strike at one factory and has led to virtual shutdown of North American operations; dispute has laid bare emotional issues about job security, and GM's steely resolve to improve productivity to compete; both sides have escalated struggle, abetted by huge cash reserves on union side, and GM executives' desire to stand fast; UAW has $725 million strike fund and is using only $3 million a week for 9,200 striking workers and a few laid-off workers not covered by unemployment compensation; record profits at Ford and Chrysler put pressure on GM to eliminate factory-level agreements that have allowed some workers to collect full day's pay for few hours work, and left GM with highest labor costs in industry; biggest productivity problems are in parts plants, which have least flexible work rules and most antiquated machinery; GM also wants to sell inefficient Delphi subsidiary, which makes small low-tech parts, but union objects; list showing dwindling GM inventory (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: INTERNATIONAL A3-9 Accord Reached on Loans To Help Russian Economy The Russian Government and international lenders concluded an agreement aimed at easing Russia's financial crisis and restoring confidence in its economy. The agreement would provide $17.1 billion in additional loans over the next two years. Combined with existing international assistance, the new pact would bring total lending to Russia to $22.6 billion this year and next. A1

docs.lead_paragraph: The letter was handwritten on lined dime-store paper, suggesting a homespun spontaneity. ''Entire forests are dying from disease,'' a Long Island teacher wrote. ''If you press hard for acid rain legislation in this session of Congress, I may never have to teach anything more than the beauty and wonders of nature!'' But the note was actually one of thousands written quite unspontaneously at the behest of environmental groups last spring. And like the paper plates bearing messages from immigrants, the postcards from people with AIDS and the phone calls from opponents of smoking, they were part of well-coordinated efforts to influence one man: Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato, the Long Island Republican.

headline.main: Courting D'Amato on a Shoestring; Some Grass-Roots Liberal Groups Apply Election-Year Pressure

docs.abstract: Sen Alfonse M D'Amato, no stranger to high-priced lobbying of powerful interest groups, opens himself to less-familiar pressure groups come election time; he has been getting earful of low-budget advocacy from nonprofit organizations representing immigrants, environmentalists, gay people and other constituencies better known for their ties to New York Democrats; groups are training their attention on D'Amato this year, hoping that election-year pressures will cause him to push harder on issues he might have ignored or opposed where he not seeking votes; photos (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Does a poor man have as much right to sex as a rich man? Ask anybody that question, and the answer will be yes. For that reason, the recent decision by Kaiser Permanente, the health plan of nine million people nationwide, not to cover the cost of the potency pill Viagra will meet with disapproval.

headline.main: Essay; Is There a Right to Sex?

docs.abstract: William Safire Op-Ed column contends that Kaiser Permanente's decision not to cover cost of potency pill Viagra because it costs too much has raised larger issue that politicians hate to confront: should medicine be rationed, and if so, by whom (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Frustrated by deadlocked talks to end a crippling strike at two auto parts factories here, the chief negotiator for General Motors announced late this afternoon that he would return to his office in Detroit, while the top union negotiator warned that it would be difficult to settle the strike before mid-August. The company's top negotiator, Gerald Knechtel, vice president for North American personnel, said that G.M., the world's largest auto maker, would pursue a three-week-old legal grievance against the United Automobile Workers union. The company has accused the union of using the parts factories to stage an illegal national strike although G.M.'s national agreement with the U.A.W. has more than a year to run. The union denies the accusation, and the issue will go to arbitration.

headline.main: High-Level Talks Collapse In General Motors Strike

docs.abstract: General Motors chief negotiator Gerald Knechtel, frustrated by deadlocked talks to end crippling strike at two auto parts factories in Flint, Mich, says he will return to his Detroit office; top union negotiator Richard Shoemaker warns that it will be difficult to settle strike before mid-Aug (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: For the last several months, sleepy commuters in Kanagawa prefecture southwest of Tokyo have been jolted out of their stupor by a strange sight: a dapper, blue-eyed Caucasian bowing to them deeply and, in flawless Japanese, exhorting them to vote for him on July 12.. There's more than a little of Mr. Smith in Marutei Tsurunen. Born a Finn, he overcame tremendous odds and obstacles to become a Japanese citizen in 1979 and now hopes to become a member of Japan's Upper House of Parliament.

headline.main: Foreign, Yet Japanese, and Aiming for Parliament

docs.abstract: Marutei Tsurunen, native of Finland who overcame tremendous odds and obstacles to become Japanese citizen in 1979, hopes to become member of Japan's Upper House of Parliament; came to Japan as Lutheran missionary in 1967, left ministry, married Japanese woman and opened English-language school; is running as independent and hopes to open political system in Japan and make it work for people of his prefecture; newspapers put his chances of winning at 50-50; photo; map (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Betsy McCaughey Ross is settled in the back seat of her Chevrolet Suburban, her stockinged feet curled in a swirl of papers, pumps and candy wrappers, a Hershey bar in one hand, a car phone in the other. She has a question. She has just spoken at a Planned Parenthood meeting in Albany and is now focusing on her next campaign appearance, a speech to the Nassau County Democratic Committee at Hofstra University on Long Island. ''What do I say?'' she asks an aide back at campaign headquarters, then lets out a sharp burst of awkward laughter. In truth, the Lieutenant Governor of the State of New York -- and candidate to unseat the Governor (and her boss), George E. Pataki -- sounds more quizzical than worried as her vehicle hurtles down the Thruway. McCaughey Ross presents herself less as a politician than a writer and an academic -- ''I believe in the power of ideas,'' she often says -- but ideas are not on the agenda at the Democratic meeting tonight, and she knows it. Clicking off the phone, she turns to an adviser next to her in the back seat. ''I don't think I should give a stump speech with policy in it, do you?'' she asks. ''Should I give my regular pre-K, H.M.O., pro-choice, economy speech?'' As she fidgets in her seat, a bundle of nervous smiles and energy, it soon becomes clear that she does know what to say, and she begins to preview her speech right there. ''I believe that every family should have affordable day care for their children so that women have a right and opportunity to succeed in the workplace,'' McCaughey Ross declares. ''Does the Republican Party believe that? No.'' Her eyes are closed tight and her face is shining as she imagines the audience response.

headline.main: Betsy McCaughey Ross Is Not Kidding

docs.abstract: Adam Nagourney article profiles Betsy McCaughey Ross, Lieutenant Governor turned Democrat, who is running against her boss, Republican Governor George E Pataki; describes McCaughey Ross as singularly intelligent, driven, charming person who is accustomed to getting what she wants; says Ross saw her opportunity to enter race--consisting of weak field of Democratic candidates--and took it, aided by financial support from her wealthy husband, Wilbur L Ross Jr; notes, however, McCaughey Ross would seem to be ill suited for job she seeks for number of reasons, particularly because her management style can be only described as disruptive; she also lacks the needed knowledge of history and habits of Albany, and has no grounding in any of political parties; even her friends take pause at thought of McCaughey Ross running government of New York State; photos (L)
